tit.cmt: タイトルのため、単語の頭文字を大文字に変更

sen.j: 東久世家（ひがしくぜけ）は、羽林家の家格を有する公家。
sen.e: The Higashikuze family was a Kuge who had the family grade of Urin.
The Higashikuze family was a Kuge who had the family grade of Urin.
The Higashikuze family was a Kuge who had the family grade of Urin.
Kuga family of the Murakami Genji
Kuga family of the Murakami Genji
Koga family of the Murakami-Genji (Minamoto clan).
sen.cmt: Kuga family→Koga familyに修正Murakami Genji→Murakami-Genji (Minamoto clan)とし、ピリオド追加

sen.e: Its family crest is Sasarindo.
Its family crest is Sasarindo.
Its Kamon (family crest) is Sasarindo (bamboo grass and gentians).
sen.cmt: Sasarindoの補足追加family crest→Kamon (family crest)に変更

sen.e: The family had 30 koku and fed 3 persons.
The family had 30 koku and fed 3 people.
The family had 30 koku and fed three people.

sen.j: 江戸時代初期に創設された新家。
sen.e: The family was a Shinke (new family) established in the early times of the Edo period.
The family was a Shinke (new family) established in the early times of the Edo period.
The family was a Shinke (new family) established in the early times of the Edo period.
After the Meiji Restoration, the head of the family was given the title of Count.
After the Meiji Restoration, the head of the family was given the title of Count.
After the Meiji Restoration, the head of the family was given the title of Count.

sen.j: 大納言久我通堅の三男・参議久我通廉によって江戸時代当初に創設されたとされるが、その他、東久世家の起源には諸説あり、通廉を通堅の子下津俸庵（下津俸庵）の子とする説や、または、祖秀は久我晴通の孫で、祖秀の孫が通廉とする説などがある。
sen.e: It is said that the family was established in the Edo period by Michiyasu KOGA, the Sangi (Director of palace affaires) and the third son of Michikata KOGA who was the Major councelor, but there are several views on the origin of the Higashikuze family: some say that Michiyasu was the child of Boan SHIMOZU who was the child of Michikata and others say that Motohide was the grandchild of Harumichi KOGA and that the grandchild of Motohide was Michiyasu.

It is said that the family was established in the Edo period by Michiyasu KOGA, the Sangi (Director of palace affaires) and the third son of Michikata KOGA who was the Major councelor, but there are several views on the origin of the Higashikuze family: some say that Michiyasu was the child of Boan SHIMOZU who was the child of Michikata and others say that Motohide was the grandchild of Harumichi KOGA and that the grandchild of Motohide was Michiyasu.

It is said that the family was established in the Edo period by Michiyasu KOGA, the Sangi (Director of palace affaires) and the third son of Michikata KOGA who was Dainagon (chief councilor of state), but there are several views on the origin of the Higashikuze family: some say that Michiyasu was the child of Boan SHIMOZU who was the child of Michikata and others say that Motohide was the grandchild of Harumichi KOGA and that the grandchild of Motohide was Michiyasu.
sen.cmt: the Major councelor→Dainagon (chief councilor of state)に修正

sen.j: 祖秀は武士になり、加藤清正に仕えていたが、後に帰洛したらしい。
sen.e: Motohide bacame a worrier and served Kiyomasa KATO and later, he returned to Kyoto.
Motohide bacame a warrior and served Kiyomasa KATO and later, he returned to Kyoto.
Motohide bacame a warrior and served Kiyomasa KATO and later, he returned to Kyoto.

sen.j: 幕末の東久世通禧は、尊王攘夷派の少壮公家の一人で、文久3年（1863年）八月十八日の政変後に「七卿落ち」を余儀なくされた。
sen.e: Michitomi HIGASHIKUZE, who lived at the end of the Edo period, was one of the court nobles belonging to the group of Sonno-joi and was forced to experience the 'Nanakyoochi' after the political change on August 18, 1863.

Michitomi HIGASHIKUZE, who lived at the end of the Edo period, was one of the court nobles belonging to the group of Sonno-joi and was forced to experience the 'Nanakyoochi' after the political change on August 18, 1863.

Michitomi HIGASHIKUZE, who lived at the end of the Edo period, was one of the court nobles belonging to the group of Sonno-joi (19th century slogan advocating reverence for the Emperor and the expulsion of foreigners) and was forced to experience the 'Shichikyo-ochi,' or the exile of the Seven nobles from Kyoto, after the Coup of August 18, 1863 (September 30, 1863 in new calendar).
sen.cmt: Sonno-joiの補足追加Nanakyoochi→Shichikyo-ochiとし、補足追加「八月十八日の政変」→the Coup of August 18とし、新暦表記を後に追加

sen.j: 明治維新後、通禧は外国事務総督、神奈川府知事、開拓使長官、侍従長、元老院 (日本)副議長、貴族院 (日本)副議長、枢密院 (日本)副議長を歴任し、明治17年（1884年）伯爵に叙される。
sen.e: After the Meiji Restoration, Michitomi held the posts of: Governor-general for foreign affairs, Director of the Development Comission, Grand Chamberain, Vice-president of the Chamber of Elders, Vice-president of the House of Peers and Vice-president of the Privy Council, and he was given the title of count in 1884.

After the Meiji Restoration, Michitomi held the posts of: Governor-general for foreign affairs, Director of the Development Comission, Grand Chamberain, Vice-president of the Chamber of Elders, Vice-president of the House of Peers and Vice-president of the Privy Council, and he was given the title of count in 1884.

After the Meiji Restoration, Michitomi held the posts of: Governor-general for foreign affairs, Governor of Kanagawa Prefecture, Director of the Development Comission, Grand Chamberain, Vice-president of the Chamber of Elders, Vice-president of the House of Peers and Vice-president of the Privy Council, and he was given the title of count in 1884.

sen.j: また、通禧の四男・秀雄も男爵に叙される。
sen.e: Also, Hideo, the fourth son of the Michitomi, was given the title of baron.
Also, Hideo, the fourth son of the Michitomi, was given the title of baron.
Also, Hideo, the fourth son of the Michitomi, was given the title of baron.
